fields.Description/Abstract:
From “No Name Woman” to Gu Liu Xin: 
Ghost Writing in Amy Tan’s The Bonesetter’s Daughter

In the epilogue to The Bonesetter’s Daughter, Amy Tan offers a scene that combines the adult writer, Ruth Young, at her desk developing a story with the writer’s childhood memory of writing messages from a ghost on a tea-tray lined with sand. By fusing the two in one scene, Tan provides an apt metaphor for the work she performs throughout her fiction, that of investigating and reclaiming aspects of the past in order to define the self, align it with female ancestors, and orient it toward the future. The image of the daughter at the tea-tray writing out messages from the dead symbolizes the “possession” of the daughter by her ghostly female ancestor. This possession is not a passive state but an active one, for the daughter exercises her agency as a writer by using her imagination and responding through her written words to the to her mother about Precious Auntie.
Moreover, the story of Precious Auntie in The Bonesetter’s Daughter may be interpreted as a creative adaptation of “No Name Woman,” the first chapter of Maxine Hong Kingston’s The Woman Warrior. Tan borrows the topos of the patriarchal silencing of women from Kingston as well as the imagery of paper and ink to recover the silenced female ancestor.
In The Bonesetter’s Daughter, the fact that the family manufactures ink is a critical feature of LiLing’s childhood experience and her relationship with Precious Auntie.  Given that ink is the means by which Precious Auntie tries to kill herself (the first time) and instead injures and disfigures herself, it is also a primary element in the plot of Precious Auntie’s life story. LiLing’s calligraphy and Ruth’s own work as a writer are part of the family of images relating to writing in the novel. 
These images provide a strong parallel to the writing metaphors in “No Name Woman” and “White Tigers,” the first two chapters of Kingston’s Woman Warrior.  In “No Name Woman,” Kingston figures her memoir about her anonymous aunt as a tribute or homage, taking the place of origami offerings to the dead. In “White Tigers,” Kingston portrays the long section in which Maxine “becomes” Fa Mu Lan as an imaginative entering into an ink drawing, a passage that focuses on the similarity between the image of a bird in flight with that of the Chinese ideograph for “human.” This image symbolizes Kingston’s active engagement with the tale of Fa Mu Lan in her work as a writer.  In turn, Tan’s adaptation and revision of Kingston’s anonymous aunt in The Bonesetter’s Daughter similarly foregrounds images of writing. Tan does so in order to transfigure the anonymous aunt, a deliberately forgotten female ancestor, into a mother with a name and life story.
